cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1904.

div.head: GERMAN POLICY.
div.p: The statements of Count von Bülow, of which a summary appears in to-day's issue, show that for the moment the German Chancellor has received instructions to walk delicately, and speak softly. We do not know whom the Chancellor imagines he is deceiving by such statements. We have never accused Germany of trying to raise a Navy which would compete ship for ship and gun for gun with the Fleets of Great Britain. The attempt to gratify such an ambition, and at the same time to maintain their gigantic army, would involve national bankruptcy. But we find it impossible to regard this sudden access of naval ardour, and these vast naval preparations, as any thing else but a menace to the British Empire. It is all very well for Count Bülow to remark on such occasions as he did last year in the Reichstag, that the Emperor's saying, "Our future lies on the water," is not in any way pointed against other Powers. If it is not, it is utterly meaningless; and there is only one Power at whom it can be pointed.

But there is a light in which her increased and ever-increasing naval programme becomes clear as day. Without attempting to rival Great Britain single-handed, Germany sees her opportunity of becoming a dangerous makeweight in all international quarrels which can be settled at sea. If we were engaged in a struggle with two, or even with one first-class Power, it would lie with Germany to throw herself with crushing effect into the scales. Considering her ambitious aims "on the water," and her avowed and notorious jealousy of England, both as a trade rival and a world Power, it is impossible to watch her naval extension unmoved. But, as we said on Saturday last, in commenting on Germany's latest naval estimates, from her point of view Germany's policy is both natural and reasonable, and the practical thing is not to be angry with the Germans, whose duty it is to think of their country's greatness and future, but to consider the foundations, in right and in might, of the greatness of our own country, and to be forearmed, as well as forewarned.

div.head: MAD DOGS.
div.p: We hope that the report that the Govern- ment is considering the question of imposing certain restrictions on the import of foreign dogs is founded on more than the wish that such may be the case. There can, unhappily, be no question but that rabies is on the in- crease in Egypt, although the disease was till a recent date as unknown in this country, as it is to-day in parts of Arabia and Syria, and, as will be seen by a notice which appears in an- other column, a case has just occurred in the Sudan. With the prevalence of rabies, comes increased risk to man from hydrophobia, the most horrible and deadly of diseases, but while our Anti-Rabic Institute has done useful work, the best safeguard is the application of some kind of quarantine detention to all im ported dogs. Killing pariah dogs by lead and poison in quarters where mad dogs have been at large is a sound precaution,-pace our senti- mentalists, the same lot that denbunced the "cruel and. hateful" muzzling order-but as respectable house dogs have no immunity from being bitten, it cannot be considered as a thorough guarantee against risks. Muzzling is, we fear, quite impracticable. It could only be enforced in parts of the large towns and would greatly encourage nightly thieves, while in the villages it is unthinkable. If the disease is not really native to Egypt, it is possible that by combining, with quarantine for imported dogs, a series of measures calculated to facilitate the work of the police and sanitary authorities, it might be stamped out.

We should suggest that to attain this end the pariahs, useless and noxious beasts, should be attacked with the utmost vigour, that all dogs which are the property of individuals should, at least in the towns, wear collars bearing the names of their owners, and that concealment of the fact that a dog has deve- loped suspicious symptoms, or has boon bitten by a dog believed to be mad, should be se- verely dealt with, though the common-sense of owners will probably be sufficient to prevent their contravening any such regulations. We have no intention to recommend measures, such as the general muzzling of dogs or the compulsory inoculation of animals that may have been bitten, as is practised in some Ame rican municipalities. These are impossible in a country that has not reached the same pitch of development as most of the States of Europe, but we think that vigorous action on the part of the authorities in the near future may yet save lives valuable to the community.

div.head: THE WAR.
div.p: JAPS DRIVEN OFF.
RUSSIANS IN PURSUIT.
ST. PETERSBURG, November 29.

General Kuropatkin reports that the fighting at Tsinkhe-chou was resumed yesterday. The Japanese were driven off. The Russians collected 230 Japanese dead. They captured a quantity of rifles, ammunition, and entrenching tools, and pursued the retiring Japanese. (Reuter.)

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: EXACT POSITION.
OFFICIAL STATEMENT.
TOKIO, November 29.

An official statement gives the exact position at Port Arthur. It runs as follows:-"We firmly hold the crests of the glacis of Sung- shu-shan and the forts eastward, but it is not yet time to storm the fortress. At present we are destroying the casemates on a 203 metre hill. We have stormed the trenches near the summit, and are now endeavouring to capture the whole fort." (Reuter.)
CHI-FU, November 29.
The Japanese are attacking a mountain 300 metres high, dominating Port Arthur. (H.)
ON THE SHA-HO.
SITUATION UNCHANGED.
TOKIO, November 29.
The situation on the Sha-Ho on the 27th
was unchanged.
(Reuter)

div.p: FRANCE'S REPRESENTATIVE
PARIS, November 29.
Admiral Fournier will represent France on the International Commission over the Hull
incident.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: ROUNDING THE CAPE.
CAPETOWN, November 29.
The Argus announces that Admiral Rod- Jestvensky's fleet is coaling off Swakopmund.
(Reuter).

div.head: THE COALING QUESTION. CARDIFF MERCHANTS POSITION.
div.p: LONDON, November 29.

With reference to Lord Lansdowne's warning, Cardiff merchants state that the export of coal for Russia and Japan cannot be stopped under present circumstances. Most of the shipments for Russia are carried out by German firms, the destination being successfully concealed. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN DESTROYER DOCKED.
div.p: BREST, November 29.
The Russian destroyer Pronzitelny, while
raising anchor here, pierced her hull, and was
afterwards docked.
(Reuter.)

div.head: DEPARTURE OF RUSSIAN GENERAL.
div.p: ODESSA, November 29.
General Caulbars has left. He will arrive at Mukden on the 14th December. (Reuter.)

div.head: EXPLOSION AT PORTSMOUTH. TWO LAUNCHES SUNK.
div.p: PORTSMOUTH, November 29.

Two launches, whilst engaged in mine sweeping practice in the harbour bere, were sunk as the result of an explosion. The cause of the explosion is obscure. One of the launches was blown to pieces, two men being killed and several injured, (Reuter.)

div.head: THE
div.p: BRITAIN AND GERMANY.
COUNT BULOW AND BRITISH HOSTILITY.
REMARKABLE INTERVIEW.
LONDON, November 29.

A remarkable interview with Count von Bülow has been published by the Nineteenth Century. He deplores the British hostility, and the unceasing suspicion of Germany, and warmly denies the attempts to incite Russia against Great Britain in connection with Thibet or the Baltic Fleet incident. He repudiates the suggestion that Germany has attempted to tamper with the Anglo-French friendship. The blundering intrigues ascribed to Germany could have no effect on the sincerity of an entente such as this one. Count von Bülow energetically refutes the allegation that Ger- many is preparing for a naval war against England. This would be a monstrous crime. which would completely destroy German and partially destroy British trade for the benefit only of our rivals, who would proceed to capture the Anglo-German markets without firing a shot. (Reuter.)

div.head: EARL OF HARDWICKE DEAD.
div.p: LONDON, November 29.
The Earl of Hardwicke has died suddenly, (Reuter.)
The late Earl of Hardwicke was a promising young peer, and had already made his mark in the political world.
Albert Edward Philip Henry Yorke, 6th Earl of Hardwicke, had filled the office of Under-Secretary of War in the British Govern- ment since 1902, previous to which he was Under-Secretary for India.

He was born at the British Embassy, Paris, 14th March, 1867, and was theretore in his 38th year. He bore a distinguished title, the first earl having been the great lawyer who filled the office of Lord High Chancellor in 1754.

div.p: We are compelled to hold over our notice of last night's performance of Rigoletto until to-morrow.

div.p: The Ministries will be closed from Wednesday, 7th proxo., to Sunday, the 11th, during the Beyram holidays.

div.p: found in the Minet-el-Bassal and Attarin quarters of Alex- andria on the 5th proxo. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: FRENCH DEPUTY.-
div.p: The election of the 2nd Deputé de la Nation to replace Mr. Paul Oziot will be held on Saturday next at the French Consulate.

div.head: THE CYPRUS JOURNAL
PRINCE AZIZ'S GENEROSITY.-
div.p: The Mugahid Mosque at Alexandria has been entirely re paired and restored at the expense of Prince Aziz Bey Hassan. The inauguration of the restored mosque took place on Friday last.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.-
div.p: The Castellano Ita lian opera company closed its season at the Alhambra yesterday evening with I Puritani. The company leaves to-morrow for Athens. On Friday next, the boards of the theatre will be occupied by Prof. Fedik, an expert in the occult sciences, who will give a spiritualistic
seance.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.-
div.p: The boards of this theatre will shortly be occupied by a first-class Italian operetta company, which is leaving Trieste on the 15th proxo. for Alex- andria. We are promised a very interesting series of performances, as the company, which is under the management of Sig. Soarez, is one of the best known in Italy.

div.head: MESSES.
div.p: THOS. COOK AND SON (EGYPT) Ltd., announce, with much regret, that Mr. A. P. Cavafy, who for the past six years has represented them in Alexandria, has, owing to ill-health, resigned his position. He will be succeeded from the 15th December by Mr. Vincent Fiteni, who has hitherto been chief clerk of the Alexandria office.

div.head: POPULAR UNIVERSITY.-
div.p: Commandant Benito Sylvain, Special Envoy of the Republic of Hayti to the Emperor Menelik of Abyssinia, will deliver a lecture in French on "The necessity for agreement between the white and black races in Africa," at the University on Thurs- day, 1st proxo., at 9.15 p.m. M. Sylvain recently gave the same lecture before the mem- bers of the Khedivial Geographical Society.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive, in accordance with the usage on the last Friday in Ramadan, will visit the Mosque of Omar at Old Cairo next Friday.

No. 4 Battery Egyptian Artillery will parade at the mosque at 11 a.m. in order to fire a salute of 21 guns as his Highness enters and leaves the sacred building. The 16th Battalion and the Cavalry Band will form a guard of honour.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: A London contemporary remarks :- The exodus of the British army of occupa eat tion from Egypt may be commended on such igh grounds as the withdrawal of a standing offence to the Khedive, and a further limitation of the amount of foreign service entailed upon our troops. Still, Egypt has always been an advanc ed post connecting England with India, and reinforcements could always be very quickly forwarded to the East by the Nile route. Rail- way communication is now nearly unbroken Iria between the Mediterranean and the Red Sea, and must expedite the movement of troops to Bombay and onward. The importance at of Egypt as a near support has no doubt m. been much reduced by the sound defen- cive policy now foreshadowed by Lord Kit ive chener. He was not the first, perhaps, to ikh see the paramount necessity for concentrating strength where possible danger threatened, but it has been on his initiative that steps will be to taken to collect the Indian garrisons within nce near reach of the North-West frontier. Time must elapse, however, and much money must be spent, before the project becomes rom accomplished fact. The provision th, adequate barrack accommodation is an indis pensable preliminary, and in view of the burthens upon the Indian Exchequer it can the only be slowly achieved. But a comprehen lex- sive scheme has now taken shape, and ere by long the Russian invasion bogey will be effec tually laid. Modern warfare makes mostly for the defence-witness Port Arthur; and a 2nd defence, backed by adequate forces conve ziot niently placed to resist attack, may reasonably nch be called impregnable.
of
TOR'S WATER SUPPLY.
The Ministry of Finance has opened a fresh credit of £10,000 for building the two dams for storing water at the Quarantine Camp at Tor.
MANSOURAH'S WATER SUPPLY.

The Municipal Commission of Mansourah bas taken the question of the water supply of that town seriously in hand. The water-works and the pipes are just finished and the embranchments for the distribution of filtered water to private houses will shortly be com menced.

div.head: CANEA OUTRAGES.
div.p: M. MAXIMOFF'S STATEMENTS.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE Sir,-As the statements of the Russian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General anent he Canea incident absolutely contradict the acts recounted in my interview with you, and published in the Gazette of Monday last, I ake this opportunity of declaring that I was at Canea for thirteen days, and only left there on Thursday last, after the Baltic fleat had de- parted, and that my statements as to the conduct fthe Russian officers and men during their stay n Crete form the truthful report of an eye- witness. I have no possible reason for inventing or exaggerating the facts, and any enquiries made in the island will fully corroborate the ame. M. Maximoff admits that, "les marins russes font comme les autres, avec cette diffé- ence pourtant, qu'habitués à ne boire que de eau-de-vie saine, lorsqu'ils ont trop bu, ils ombent dans un sommeil profond, pendant equel ils sont incapables de nuire à personne." This is true enough, but before the Bus- ians reached the somnolent stage of inebriety hey passed through terrible paroxysms of ctivity, Possibly the somnolent stage is, more quickly reached when Muscovite eau-de-vie only is partaken of Bup at Canea the only fiery spirit which was obtainable was a Daneful concoction entitled Greek cognac, which they drank neat in big tumblerfuis. However, I need not attempt to justify my statements, as the despatch from Benter's Correspondent, a native of the island, publish ed in the London newspapers, absolutely sub- stantiates the facts as related by me. That gentleman, I may remark, is personally un- known to me, and during my recent visit to Crete I never had the pleasure of meeting him. I am, Sir,
Faithfully yours,
H.M.S. "FOX."
Suez, Wednesday. The British cruiser For sailed this morning bound for Aden.

div.head: THE GREEK NAVY.
div.p: The Greek workmen employed in the large tobacco factory of Mr, Laurens in Alexandria have sent this morning to their consulate an olive wood sealed box containing 350 francs, the savings from two months' wages, for pre- sentation to the funds of the Greek Navy. The Consul tendered them his thanks in the name of the Greek nation.
GREEK FLEET'S VISIT.
The following paragraph appeared recently in the Telegraphos

"M. Scotides, the Hellenic Consul-General at Alexandria, inspired by a paragraph which appeared in our columns, has forwarded to the Hellenic Foreign Office at Athens the issues of the Egyptian Gazette containing the reports of the doings at Alexandria on the occasion of the visit of the Hellenic Squadron, in order to show the sentiments, which were entertained by Anglo-Egyptian official and non- official society on that occasion."

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: The two cases of plague at Toukh were dis- charged as cured yesterday. A fatal case is reported to-day in the same district.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SANITATION.
div.p: A correspondent writes :-The leading ar ticle in the Gazette on sanitation deserves careful consideration, as all the chief causes for the high rate of mortality here are preventable
with the diffusion of education in the most simple sanitary rules. The three great (and preventable) causes of the high mortality in Egypt are:-
(1) Among children in unsuitable diet. Breast fed children getting cucumbers and melons to eat; that sets up acute gastro-enteritis, followed nearly always by death.

(2) Among adults in the country (as op posed to the town), chiefly the parasite known as Bilhargia Nacmatobia-drunk, in unfiltered water; water, drunk in the Nile and its canals from the running stream.
(3) Also among adults the Anchlystoms duodenale, a parasite found chiefly, in the earth, and usually swallowed from soiled hands and unwashed vegetables.
The Bilhargia causes kidney and intestinal mischief, the Anchlystoma causes dysenteric symptoms and profound anemia.

div.head: RABIES IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: SYMPTOMS DESCRIBED.
Khartoum Nov

In consequence, of a case of hydrophobia having occurred here the following notes and instructions for the detection of rabies in dogs, by Lieut. Col. Griffiths, P.V.O., have been published for the general information of the public
Rabies appears in two forms
t
(1) True or Furious rabies and (2) Dumb rabies. MEAT WEE SEUNSOL

(1) True or Furious rabies symptoms: Animal becomes dull, gloomy, seeks to isolate itself, retiring in corners, quite different to its habits, gets restless, uneasy and fidget. Later this gives place to a most characteristio symptom :-
Taste becomes depraved, the dog has a desire to bite and swallow anything in its reach: wood, grass, stones and manure.
Mad dog does not foam at the month to any extent at first, but the mucus of the mouth becomes thick, adhering to the angles. At this period thirst becomes intense:
Rabid animals are not afraid of water.

The voice of a rabid, dog is most peculiar and characteristic of the disease, The alteration in the voice is sometimes the first observable indication of the malady and should attract attention and cause enquiry.
A rabid dog is usually very excited, the sight of another dog often inducing a fit of fury. This can be used as test in a suspected animal:-

When a dog suddenly takes to being aggres- sive to other dogs, precautions should be taken. In the large majority of instances the dog is inoffensive at the early period of the disease to those with whom it is familiar, and runs away from its home.

After two or three days the ferocious in- stincts are developed. The animal has an ex- pression of melancholy and cruelty. If caged it flies at the spectator, emitting its characteris- tic howl or bark, seizing the iron bars with its teeth. The fury is soon succeeded by lassitude and animal remains insensible to every excite- ment, then all at once may have another pa- roxysm of fury
(2) Damb rabies symptoms:-

The lower jaw drops, mouth dry and as- gumes a deep red colour. In this condition the creature is not very dangerous as it cannot bite and there does seem a desire to do so. The saliva from the mouth is none the less virulent. The dog in this stage often gives one the idea that something has lodged in its throat.

Incubation. From seven days; but three to ten weeks in majority of cases. Several well-authenticated instances have been known to occur in which the interval was over twelve months; therefore a bitten dog cannot be con- sidered safe before the lapse of twelve months though evidence would tend to show that after six the risk is not great..

div.head: CHURCH OF ENGLAND IN EGYPT.
div.p: The following letter has been addressed to the members of the Church of England in Egypt by Bishop Morley

My dear Friends,-By the appointment of the Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem, I have taken up the Office of Archdeacon of the Church of England in Egypt. The warm welcome I have received in Alexandria has been a great pleasure and, encouragement. My wish is to be a help to the Bishop and to yourselves, both Clergy and Laity, and I trust that, with increased knowledge of the religious work and needs of Egypt, I may be enabled, in consulta tion with representatives of the Church, to devise means whereby Churchmen may to the best advantage afford their help, As the British are, we have reason to believe, the means of benefit in temporal matters, so may they increasingly be in spiritual things, in this land of Egypt. May the Great Head of the Church guide us in all things.-Believe me, Your faithful Brother in Chirst, S. Morley, Bishop, (Archdeacon of the Church of England in Egypt).

div.head: NATIVE GIRLS EDUCATION.
div.p: The movement among the Native Moslems in favour of increasing the facilities for girls education is, we are glad to say, slowly but surely growing. Mansour Bey Youssef, a wealthly Alexandrian, has presented a thous and pics of land at Baghous Station to the Orwa el-Woska Society for building a girls school.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAYS.
div.p: A correspondent writes: Would it not be possible for the Cairo Tramway Company to give the publia some first-class carriages 1 The little boxes which do duty as Suoh are lament- ably insufficienty and one may see half-a-dozen trams pass at Ataba el-Khadra before a car supplied even with these so-called first-class compartments turns up For respectable women, European, Syrian, Coptic, and Jewish, it is a great hardship to be obliged to sit next natives, of the lowest class, who frequently nidge, and press against European women, who are travelling alone, and indulge in the in- decent pleasantries so dear to the canaille, without fear of reprisals. There are ladies compartments, but these labour under the same defect as the first-class carriages. Cannot Cairo follow the example of Alexandria 1

div.head: RED SEA LIGHTHOUSES
div.p: Messrs. Johnson and Rackastraw will shortly cease to be employed on the Red Sea light houses by the Ports and Lighthouses Admi- nistration, owing to the state of their health. We have to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of a parcel of books for the use of the Red Sea lightkeepers, from Mr. W. J. B.Webb.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The draft of 67 non commissioned officers and men of the Military Mounted Police which left Aldershot the other day for Egypt will bring the M. M. Pain that country up to the full squadron strength of 120 of all ranks. It may be remembered that same years ago a squadron of the 20th Hussars, replaced by one of the 17th Lancers, was the only British valry maintained in Egypt. As already stated in these notes, the M. M. P. will in the future larghly discharge the duties formerly carried out by the cavalry regiment, stationed at Cairo. How long this arrangement will successfully work remains to be seen.
Captain Charles Burroughs, the Provost Marshal.and....commanding officer of the M.M.P., saw considerable service in the Boer War and was mentioned in despatches by Lord Kitchener for good work.

Captain A. E. M. Barnett, M.V.O., D.S.O., Squadron Commander in the 25th Cavalry (Frontier Force) at Kohat, has been selected for service with the Egyptian Army, and he joins the Khediye's army with the reputation of being a smart and energetic officer-like most north countrymen. Hajoined the Border Regiment in 1889 and reached his present rank in July, 1900. He served in the Manipore Expedition 1891 (medal with clasp), He re- ceived the D.S.O. for services in the late campaign.
Lieutenant C. F. N. Bartlett, 1st Battalion Royal Berks Regiment at Dublin, has been ordered to join the 2nd Battalion at Alex andria.

In a gun-layer's competition for the Channel Fleet the first-class battleship Lupiter, with her 12-in. guns, made nineteen direct hits out of fifty-six rounds, and with her 6-in. guns she scored no less than eighty seven, hits out of 162 rounds. Vice-Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, the Commander-in-Chief, signalled his congratulations to the ship on the result. The 12-in. gun-firing of the first-class battle- ship Hannibal was disappointing, there being only nine hits out of forty-three rounds. With her 6-in: guns, however, she did much better, scoring ninety-three hits in 158 rounds. The best of the 6-in. guns made fourteen hits during seventeen rounds fired in two minutes, while the best group of seamen fired forty-six rounds and, made, thirty three hits. The best 6-in. gun of the Jupiter fired sixteen rounds in the time allowed and scored fourteen hits. It would have been a bad job for the Baltic Fleet had it blundered into the ships manned by "Lord Charlie's" handy men....

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We learn on good, authority that Harari Pasha and Michalla Pasha will both retire early next year.

We also hear that Harari Pashays after his retirement, will enter the service of Sin Emest Cassel, to act as a sort of controller, general of Sir Ernest's numerous undertakings in Egypt at salary which, rumour states, is as high as L.E.3,000 per annum.
Chitty Bey Director-General of Customs, left for Cairo yesterday on work connected with the Administration. He will return on Friday evening

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: E. G. DEBBAS.

We regret to announce the death of Mr. Elias G. Debbas, which occurred at, his residence at Alexandria this morning from heart disease... The deceased gentlemanwalome of the most respected members of this Byriam colony, and on the Bourse this morning his death was the subject of general condelenee. As a sign of the respect felt by the com- mercial community of Alexandria towards the deceased, the business of the Produce Brokers Association was suspended this morning for half-an-hour, and the stock and share market for the same time.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: COUR D'APPEL MIXTE
LA BONNE FOI EN MATIERE COMMERCIALE

M. Xenophon Constantinidis, correspondant de la maison Arthur Mondi, de Bordeaux, était débiteur d'ane certaine Bomme vis-à-vis de cette maison; il avait annoncé par lettre à sa créancière qu'il avait versé un acompte de 20 £ à M. Playan, voyageur attitré de la maison Mondi. Celle-ci, tout en accusant réception de cette lettre, réclamait le paiement du solde de la dette. Plus tard, s'étant aperçue que les 20£ n'avaient pas été payées, la maison Mondi en réclams le paiement et demanda en première instance une mesure d'instruction qui lui permit d'établir l'exis tence de la créance. Les premiers jages ont retenu que la lettre d'accusé de récep tion dans laquelle la maison ne réclamait que le solde de sa créance suffisait à établir le paiement des 20£. La Cour en a jugé autrement et partant du principe que la bonne foi est admise en matière commerciale, elle n'a pas considéré M. Constantinidis quitte d'une somme de 20 £, parce que la maison avait oru faussement, sur la foi d'une lettre de lai, que cette somme avait été versée.
Voici dans ces grandes lignes le dispositif de l'arrêt :

La Cour infirme le jugement de première instance, déclare Xenophon Constantinidis en état de faillite, fixe provisoirement au 2 juin la date de la cessation de paiement, nomme le juge Soubhi Bey Ghali jugecommissaire et M. Méguirditjian syndic provisoire, ordonne la mise des scellés sur tous les biens meubles du failli et, en application de l'art. nouveau 248 da Code de Commerce, ordonne que le failli sera gardé par un officier de police et met les frais à la charge de la masse; dit que le présent Arrêt sera exécutoire sans caution et sur minute.
TRIBUNAL COMMERCIAL MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE
Giuseppe Rovigo contre Chitty Boy. Voici les faits:

M. Rovigo ayant à bord du Cleopatra une motocyclette et divers effets retira ceux-ci le matin même de l'arrivée du bateau à Alexandrie et retourna le soir prendre sa motocyclette sur laquelle il monta pour se diriger vers l'entrée ordinaire. Là il fut arrêté par un douanier, conduit à la douane où sa motocyclette fut saisie, et obligé de verser un dépôt de 6 £. pour éviter d'être mené au Caracol. Il fut condamné par la Commission Douanière. Le tribunal de commerce devant lequel Rovigo a fait opposition de la décision douanière vient de confirmer cette décision purement et simplement et de le condamner aux frais de l'instance. Il est probable cependant qu'il va interjeter appel.

Voici le dispositif de ce jugement: Statuant publiquement et contradic- toirement, le Ministère public entendu; écartant toutes conclusions plus amples ou contraires; rejette l'opposition formée par le sieur Rovigo, dit pour droit que la décision de la Commission Douanière d'Alexandrie du 14 novembre 1904 sortira son plein et entier effet. Condamine l'opposant, Giuseppe Rovigo,à payer à l'administration des Douanes la somme da 8 L.E. et 800 millièmes, le condamne aux dépens, taxe les honoraires de l'avocat de la douane à P.T. 800.

Me Ouzzer, avocat de M. Rovigo, a bien voulu nous communiquer ses conclusions pour en extraire les principaux arguments: Pour établir qu'il y a eu tentative de contrebande, il fut le concours de deux éléments essentiels 1° que l'objet introduit soit susceptible du paiement d'un droit d'entrée ou que son introduction soit défendue, 2° qu'il y ait eu intention de frau- der le fisc et par suite mauvaise foi. Or ces éléments n'existent pas en l'espèce.
L'administration des Donanes ne conts'e pas que la motocyclette saisie soit usée mais elle pl ide qu'aux termes de T'Art. 9 du règlement douanier de 1890 Recepté par l'Autriche "les effets, meubles,

livres et autres objets à l'usage privé ne " sont admis en franchise que lorsqu'ils appartiennent à des personnes qui vien- "nent s'établir pour la première fois "dans le pays. "Ce qui n'est pas le cas pour Rovigo; mais Bovigo n'a jamais été que de passage en Egypte et de plus l'ad- ministration oublie qu'au paragraphe suivant il est indiqué comme jouissant de la franchise "les effets personnels apportés par les voyageurs et destinés à leur

usage." Or la motocyclette d'un commerçant, d'un commis-voyageur ou même d'un touriste peut bien rentrer dans cette catégorie. C'est donc par une interprétation tout à fait arbitraire da règlement douanier que la douane demande un droit d'entrée pour une motocyclette.
En cas d'ambiguité d'ailleurs on doit s'en remettre aux anciens adages "In dubis contra fiscum" et "In dubiis pro reo".

En admettant même que le droit d'entrée soit légitime, il n'y aurait pas pour cela tentative de contrebande, car Rovigo est sorti ostensiblement, sans chercher une porte moins bien gardée; il s'en est remis à l'assurance de son ami Stoya lui affirmant qu'il n'avait pas de droit à payer. Non seulement on ne lui a pas demandé s'il avait quelque chose à déclarer mais encore on l'a arrêté avant même qu'il arrivât à la porte. Bien done ne prouve la mauvaise foi chez M.Rovigo et l'on sait qu'il est de principe que la mauvaise foi ne se présume pas et qu'en matière de droit on doit établir l'intention.

div.head: Maisons Ouvrieres
div.p: La Commission aura ce soir à discuter la question relative à la construction d'habitations à boa marché. Trois solutions sont en présence: celle de la commission des locataires, celle de M. Alderson et enfin celle de M l'administrateur. Cette dernière, qui consiste à étudier plus mûrement la question, sera votée selon toute probabilité et un comité sera élu parmi les conseillers.

Un point sur lequel nous désirons attirer l'attention autant de M. Chataway et de M. Alderson que de leurs collègues c'est le taux de l'intérêt que garantira la Municipalité aux entrepreneurs de constructions ouvrières. Ces messieurs parlent du 3 0/0 dans leur rapport respectif. Or la Com- mission Municipale, dans sa séance du ler juillet 1896, voulant favoriser un mouvement dans ce sens, a admis, en principe, qu'un intérêt de 4 o/o au maximum pourrait être garanti par elle aux sociétés qui entreprendraient la construction d'habitations destinées à remplacer les échèches. Ce taux ayant été sanctionné par le Gouvernement, ce serait peu généreux de la part de la Commission de revenir maintenant sur sa décision, alors que l'entreprise de maisons économiques a plus que jamais besoin d'être encouragée.

div.head: Délégation Municipale
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 29 novembre 1904 à 9h. du soir sous la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents: MM. Mohamed Bey Saïd, Mansour Bey Youssef, E. Stross, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr G. Valensin, membres,. W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky, secrétaire.
La Délégation approuve les dispositions proposées par l'Administrateur pour la fusion des services de perception et de la propriété bâtie en vue d'en faire un seul service de recettes.

Communication est donnée du rapport du Comité spécial chargé de l'étude de la question du collecteur Est et concluant à la nécessité de la construction de ce collecteur, en le limitant cependant pour le moment à la Porte Rosette. Ce rapport sera soumis à la Commission Municipale.
Elle adopte le projet de règlement sur les chiens et la rage, prescrivant le musellement des chiens, et en proposera l'approbation à la Commission.
La Commission sera également appelée à statuer sur la note de l'Administrateur relative à la question de la construction de maisons à bon marché.
L'Administrateur dépose son rapport ainsi que son projet de budget pour l'année 1905. Ces documents seront distribués à tous les membres, pour être discutés à une prochaine séance.
La Délégation fixe sa prochaine réunion à lundi à 9h. du soir.
La séance est levée à minuit et demie.

Le marché se maintient ferme en général mais les comptes de la fin du mois entravent quelque peu l'activité de la spéculation. Le mouvement s'est borné ce matin à la Banque d'Athènes qui clôture acheteurs à 134 et à la Salt & Soda qui clôture à 39/9 acheteurs, après avoir atteint 40. On a échangé 4 à 5000 Salt dans la matinée.

La Delta Land atteint 3 7/8, les Ciments d'Egypte 108, la Nungovich 9 7/16, tandis que la Crown Brewery fléchit à 218, les Cotton Mills à 8/9 acheteurs, l'Anglo-American Nile à 4 15/16 vendeurs, et la Cairo Helouan à 29. La tendance est bonne et l'on s'attend prochainement à une reprise.

THE DIRECTORS.
Our Paris Letter.
( FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT ).

PARIS, November 22. Though we are a good month off Christmas, there are multifarious signs of it in the air. The toy merchants of the pavement are exhibiting their Christmas novelties, and the lightning carrot-scraper, the dancing bear, the fireman climbing his ladder, the boxer swinging his arms, Syveton-wise, as if there were an André in every passer-by; the automobile careering among the crowd with as much insouciance as if in real life, always attract the children and their nurses, or paterfamilias with an eye to the provisioning of Bonhomme Noël. Though traditions are departing in France, the Christmas and New Year present is not one of them. Fashions may come and fashions may go, but it lives for ever. And the favorite of them all is the box of bonbons, tied with dainty ribbon, as a gift to the fair. The ribbon, I may remark, is as important as the quality of the "marrons glacés," as it bespeaks the visit to a fashionable shop. At this moment the makers of Christmas and New Year dainties are superlatively busy in the preparation of new wonders in sugar and spice. The secret of these productions is guarded as rigorously as the Rue de la Paix watches over its latest designs. Yet in the meantime you may eat "Langues de chat au café," "Gaufrettes mignon Pihan," and "crèmes pralinées St. Georges” enough to wait calmly the coming of the greater triumphs.

General André has fallen, and the Nationalists exult in having drawn first blood. It would be hypocritical, however, to pretend that the revelation of the system impacted against the dethroned Minister and his too zealous subordinate, Captain Mollin, has come with the force of surprise upon well-informed quarters. These methods have existed to a greater or less degree for generations past : there was only a change of master, Jesuit instead of Freemason. On the whole, I prefer the Jesuit. At least, the cause was served by men of a certain eminence and intellectual standing. Nevertheless, it was, even then, sufficiently odious. In the days when the influence of Père Du Lac, the famous headmaster of the Jesuit school in the Rue des Postes, was all powerful, an officer could scarcely rise in the army unless his Catholic credentials were unexceptionable. He could only hope to become major by seniority, the higher posts for which he would be inscribed on the "tableau d'avancement,” drawn up each year by the members of the Military Council, being inevitably closed to him.

Though we do not like his methods, and the better part of the Army must be satisfied that he is no longer at its head, one must recognise & certain value in the work of General André. He has, very likely, replaced one tyranny by another, but at least it was necessary to make some change, to leaven the lump with a certain Republican yeast. Incidents could be given in plenty to show a disquieting spirit amongst the officers at the time when General André assumed office. For instance, to cite only one, there was at Rouen a crack regiment of "Chasseurs à Cheval.” Each season the Prefect gave a certain number of balls to which the officers, as well as the local personages, were invited. The officers, notwithstanding that the Prefect is the chief magistrate of a Department, and, therefore, represents the President and the Central Government, carefully abstained from attending until reminded of their duty by the colonel of the regiment, who also alluded to the fact that such attendance was traditional.. Whereupon the officers presented themselves at the Prefect's ball in parade dress-an indication that they had only acceded as a military duty and because they were forced. It was an instance of insubordination, punished in this case by the removal of the regiment from Rouen, always a coveted garrison by military men, and its transference to Lunéville, a town on the frontier, the farthest possible from Paris and its gaieties.

Though there are many cries for other "amputations'' —such, for instance, as the eccentric Minister of Marine, whose position at the head of the Fleet is infinitely more dangerous to the service than was ever André to the Army--there seems no reason to suppose that the position of M. Combes' Cabi. the net is in any way weakened by the loss of a limb. Whether, however, there is permanence in this state of affairs is, of course, another question. Already there is talk of M. Rouvier's retirement at the end of the year, and rumor even is busy with the name of the distinguished Minister for Foreign Hairs. Without these two eminent members, M. Combes' ship of State would drift hopelessly in the ocean of conflicting currents.

The Anglo-French settlement was a great achievement for the Quai d'Orsay as well as for our own Foreign Office, but as regards the portion of it applicable to Morocco, the former 18, of course, only beginning to face the most formidable part of its responsibilities. The work of "peaceful penetration" can now be approached without further delay, and it is open to French administration to gain for itself at one end of North Africa no less glorious renown than rests upon the representatives of England for their services to civilisation at the other. The French will require all the good wistres we can give them, for their task is indeed a stiff one. It is understood that the analogy of Egypt will be followed to the extent of recognising and supporting the ruling authority, so as to make the Sultan's rule both an effective security for peace and a pledge of respect for native institutions and ideals. France will do her best to temper by a firm benevolence the most unruly territory within hail of European latitudes, and if the means prove adequate to the endeavor, it will be a triumph of far more than ordinary dimensions.

The remarks of Lord Lansdowne at the Guildhall banquet on French intervention, and the discussion of the London Chamber of | Commerce favorable to the construction of the Channel Tunnel, have both been received here as welcome signs of the times. British commercial opinion in Paris is almost unanimously in favor of the tunnel, which, it is held, would be of enormous aid in the development of the commercial relations of the two countries. I had a few minutes' conversation on this subject, this afternoon, with Mr. Millington Drake, the Chairman of the British Chamber of Commerce, and a well-known man of business. Said Mr. Drake :-"The view of the London Chamber of Commerce is, I | imagine the view of most commercial men (who look at the matter from a practical, and not merely a sentimental standpoint. A tunnel I would be of great service, especially for merchandise, enabling goods to be transported without breaking bulk." |

An instance of the most intolerable kind of iconoclasm has been perpetrated by a French professor, who has ventured to cast the gravest aspersions upon the national heroine, Joan of Arc. He declared that she never won a victory, was not at Orleans during the siege, and to culminate all hinted in no uncertain manner that she was no better than she ought to have been. Popular indignation naturally rose at once to fever pitch against him. Many of the | boys of his class instantly took a holiday in protest, and a question was asked about the matter in Parliament.

Some interesting figures as to the consumption of champagne have been published by the Rheims Chamber of Commerce. From this it | appears that the number of bottles exported in the year 1903-4 was 21,084,881, against 22,523,746 in 1902-3, while that sent to home consumers was 9,808,774, against 9,235,412, and from one home merchant to another 4,316,396. The total sale of champagne in these and other ways was, for the year, | 35,210,043 bottles, against 36,535,609 in the preceding year. As the figures show, foreign of export fell off by nearly a million and a half bottles, while sales for home consumption increased more than half a million bottles.

Some superior persons are constantly girding at the musical piece which forms so large a part of the theatrical fare of the day, in London. To these people may be recommended the perusal of an article by M. Pierre Lalo in the Temps, which gives the matter from the point of view of a cultured Frenchman. M. Lalo deals with three musical comedies : The Earl and the Girl, Sergeant Brue, and The Cingalee and, greatly daring, succeeds very well in giving a sketch of the three plots. But the characteristic common to all three pieces which, he says, chiefly strikes the French | spectator is their decency. Dialogues, songs, dresses, and actors are all unexceptionable correct. But if, says M. Lalo, one of these pieces were placed on the Parisian stage all I that would be soon changed: the dialogue would be spiced, and the dresses would be curtailed, with the result that it would be quite unfit for family parties. Another thing that strikes him is the continual bustle and movement on the stage, after which the Parisian choristers appear dull and lifeless. In Eugland the actors and actresses sing far better than they do in France, and they dance with marvelous agility. The actors in England in this kind of piece are far better than those in France, says M. Lalo, but the actresses, with one exception, he considers not so clever, although they are better singers.

There was an extraordinary occurrence in a well-known Paris boulevard café three nights ago which will most probably have its sequel in the English divorce court. Four mysterious gentlemen were dining in the café in obviously ill fitting dress clothes, when to them entered a fifth. Thereupon the four guests got up and bowed. The last arrival, after a brief colloquy with the manager of the café, adjourned with the others to a private room upstairs to continue the interrupted dinner. After the meal had been completed they rose from the table, and, putting their shoulders to the door of the next room, where a lady and gentleman were enjoying a tête-à-tote dinner, forced an entrance The scene that followed baffles description. The lady, who is said to be well known in London society, fled as the fifth guest, who proved to be her husband, was dragged away from the prostrate body of her companion.

A living woman narrowly escaped being dissected at the Grenoble School of Medicine, Paris, yesterday. She had been arrested for drunkenness on the previous day and taken to the police station. Next morning she was found stiff and cold in the cell, and the doctor pronounced her to have been dead for two hours. In due course she was laid out for a post-mortem examination. But while the surgeon was getting his instruments ready the supposed corpse sat up and asked for a glass of water, to the horror of the medical man and his students. The woman was subject to epileptic fits, during which her body assumed a corpse-like rigidity,

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOLD MINING.
div.p: THE MYSORE CO. IN EGYPT.

The report of the Mysore Reefs for the year ended September 30 states that shortly after the last general meeting the Um Rus Gold Mines of Egypt was incorporated to work the Um Rus Gold Mine, and on February 5 subscriptions for shares were invited, 45,000 shares being allotted on the closing of the lists. The balance were subsequently offered for subscription, applied for, and allotted. The purchase consideration payable to the company in consideration with the flotation amounted to £61,667, which was paid as to £5,000 in cash and as to £56,667 in fully-paid shares. The prospects of the mine continue to be highly satisfactory, and a mill with the necessary machinery has been sent out and is now in course of erection. It is anticipated that the installation will be completed early in 1905, when regular returns of gold should be made. During the past year the funds of the company have been largely employed in connection with the Um | Rus Company, but nevertheless some exploratory work has been carried out in other por tions of the large area in Egypt over which the company has prospecting rights, and aurife | rous veins have been discovered. The work, however, is not yet sufficiently advanced to enable a definite opinion to be formed as to their value. The directors propose in due course to direct their attention to the development and flotation of other properties in Egypt. The auditors point out with reference to the item of £17,023 sundry debtors, that £15,692 of the amount is due from the Um Rus Gold Mines of Egypt, that sum having been lent to that company on the security of the uncalled capital.

matter of surprise and regret that British manufacturers and merchants should still leave in the hands of foreigners so large a volume, and valuable a proportion, of the trade of JEgypt. I perused with interest the contribu|tion of "One who knows,” which appeared in your issue of the 16th inst. Not being myself a trader, it is probable that I am unable to give due weight to some of his remarks, but I think I gleaned from his observations one thing, and that was that British and Continental methods, as regards deferred payment, differ considerably. Now, as far as I have been able to ascertain, Egypt has adopted the Continental system. Does your correspondent | expect that she will change it? I indulge in | no such illusions. Granted that the English practice of doing business is the sounder, that will never convert Egypt until British traders have first of all won over their Continental customers. And when do they expect to do | that I No; it seems to my uninstructed intellect that British traders who desire to capture the Egyptian markets are knocking their heads against a brick wall, and until they show their willingness to adapt themselves to Continental methods, they will never gain that proportion of Egyptian trade - which all loyal Britons would like to see them possess. With Continental and American markets closed and closing against us, Egyptian trade, which, as you, Sir, have pointed out is so rapidly expanding, and is capable of almost limitless possibilities, becomes daily of more importance. Inflexibility is a worthy national trait, but when carried to excess it becomes a short-sighted weakness. We sometimes are inclined to believe that we can teach the world everything, but when we find out, too late, that the world refuses to be taught, we have to pay somewhat dearly for those mistaken notions. Such has been our experience in the matter of Free Trade, and the same consequences are ensuing from our stubborn refusal to accommodate our system of dealing to the requirements of our Egyptian customers. "Bend, not break” | should be our motto.

Le Mardi 29 courant de 11 h. a.m. à 1 h. p.m. of de 8 h. a m. au coucher du soleil la Municipalité procédera à la vente aux enchères publiques près don cimetières Européens à la Porte-Rosette, d'ano quantité de 2,200 m. environ des pierres extraites des terrains des fortifications divisées en lots de | 40 100 m.o.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchère de 10/0 et déposer le 10 0/0 de la valeur de la mar. chandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral à la Caisse Municipale, le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication. | Ils auront à gapporter les droits de carrière au I profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres ache. tées dans un délai de dix jours sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adj diostaire.
